concise_definition: adv. 几乎不, 刚刚, 微乎其微地

definitions.explanation_en: To such a small degree or amount that it is almost negligible; barely or hardly enough to be true or noticeable.
definitions.explanation_cn: 指程度或数量极小，几乎可以忽略不计；勉强达到可被察觉或成立的程度。
definitions.example_en: She could scarcely believe her eyes when she saw the results.
definitions.example_cn: 当她看到结果时，几乎不敢相信自己的眼睛。

definitions.explanation_en: Used to emphasize that something happened only just in time or with great difficulty, often implying a narrow escape or minimal sufficiency.
definitions.explanation_cn: 用于强调某事刚刚来得及发生，或以极大的困难才得以实现，常暗示险些错过或勉强足够。
definitions.example_en: We scarcely made it to the airport before the flight departed.
definitions.example_cn: 我们刚赶在航班起飞前到达机场。

comparison.analysis: “Hardly” 与 “scarcely” 意义几乎完全相同，常可互换，都表示“几乎不”。但 “hardly” 更常用于口语，而 “scarcely” 语体稍正式，且更常与 “when” 连用构成固定结构（如 scarcely...when...）。
“Barely” 与 “scarcely” 同义，但更强调“勉强达到最低限度”，常用于数量、时间或能力的极限情境，语气更直接、更口语化。例如：barely passed（勉强及格）比 scarcely passed 更常见。
“Rarely” (很少地) 强调频率低，指某事发生的次数极少，而 “scarcely” 强调程度或数量的微不足道，不涉及频率。例如：He rarely visits his parents（他很少去看父母）≠ He scarcely speaks to his parents（他几乎不和父母说话）。
